text.div:
Name Flags Card. Type Description & Constraints
GraphDefinition TU DomainResource Definition of a graph of resources
+ Warning: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation

Elements defined in Ancestors: id, meta, implicitRules, language, text, contained, extension, modifierExtension
Interfaces Implemented: CanonicalResource
url Σ C 0..1 uri Canonical identifier for this graph definition, represented as a URI (globally unique)
+ Warning: URL should not contain | or # - these characters make processing canonical references problematic
identifier Σ 0..* Identifier Additional identifier for the GraphDefinition (business identifier)

version Σ 0..1 string Business version of the graph definition
versionAlgorithm[x] Σ 0..1 How to compare versions
Binding: Version Algorithm ( Extensible)
versionAlgorithmString string
versionAlgorithmCoding Coding
name Σ C 1..1 string Name for this graph definition (computer friendly)
title Σ T 0..1 string Name for this graph definition (human friendly)
status ?! Σ 1..1 code draft | active | retired | unknown
Binding: PublicationStatus ( Required)
experimental Σ 0..1 boolean For testing purposes, not real usage
date Σ 0..1 dateTime Date last changed
publisher Σ T 0..1 string Name of the publisher/steward (organization or individual)
contact Σ 0..* ContactDetail Contact details for the publisher

description T 0..1 markdown Natural language description of the graph definition
useContext Σ 0..* UsageContext The context that the content is intended to support

jurisdiction Σ XD 0..* CodeableConcept Intended jurisdiction for graph definition (if applicable)
Binding: Jurisdiction ValueSet ( Extensible)

purpose T 0..1 markdown Why this graph definition is defined
copyright T 0..1 markdown Use and/or publishing restrictions
copyrightLabel T 0..1 string Copyright holder and year(s)
start 0..1 id Starting Node
node 0..* BackboneElement Potential target for the link

nodeId 1..1 id Internal ID - target for link references
description 0..1 string Why this node is specified
type 1..1 code Type of resource this link refers to
Binding: Version Independent Resource Types (All) ( Required)
Additional Bindings Purpose
All Resource Types UI Binding

profile 0..1 canonical( StructureDefinition) Profile for the target resource
link 0..* BackboneElement Links this graph makes rules about

description 0..1 string Why this link is specified
min 0..1 integer Minimum occurrences for this link
max 0..1 string Maximum occurrences for this link
sourceId 1..1 id Source Node for this link
path 0..1 string Path in the resource that contains the link
sliceName 0..1 string Which slice (if profiled)
targetId 1..1 id Target Node for this link
params 0..1 string Criteria for reverse lookup
compartment 0..* BackboneElement Compartment Consistency Rules

use 1..1 code where | requires
Binding: Graph Compartment Use ( Required)
rule 1..1 code identical | matching | different | custom
Binding: Graph Compartment Rule ( Required)
code 1..1 code Patient | Encounter | RelatedPerson | Practitioner | Device | EpisodeOfCare
Binding: Compartment Type ( Required)
expression 0..1 string Custom rule, as a FHIRPath expression
description 0..1 string Documentation for FHIRPath expression

Documentation for this format

name: GraphDefinition
description: A formal computable definition of a graph of resources - that is, a coherent set of resources that form a graph by following references. The Graph Definition resource defines a set and makes rules about the set.

element.short: Definition of a graph of resources
element.definition: A formal computable definition of a graph of resources - that is, a coherent set of resources that form a graph by following references. The Graph Definition resource defines a set and makes rules about the set.

constraint.human: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: Within the context of the FHIR RESTful interactions, the resource has an id except for cases like the create and conditional update. Otherwise, the use of the resouce id depends on the given use case.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of its narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies its meaning or interpretation

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: IETF language tag for a human language

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have a narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, nor can they have their own independent transaction scope. This is allowed to be a Parameters resource if and only if it is referenced by a resource that provides context/meaning.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags in their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.short: Canonical identifier for this graph definition, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this graph definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which an authoritative instance of this graph definition is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the graph definition is stored on different servers.
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.

The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions). 

In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.
element.requirements: Allows the graph definition to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

constraint.human: URL should not contain | or # - these characters make processing canonical references problematic
All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Additional identifier for the GraphDefinition (business identifier)
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this GraphDefinition when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Business version of the graph definition
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the graph definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the graph definition author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.comment: There may be different graph definition instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the graph definition with the format [url]|[version]. The version SHOULD NOT contain a '#' - see [Business Version](resource.html#bv-format).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Indicates the mechanism used to compare versions to determine which is more current.
element.comment: If set as a string, this is a FHIRPath expression that has two additional context variables passed in - %version1 and %version2 and will return a negative number if version1 is newer, a positive number if version2 and a 0 if the version ordering can't be successfully be determined.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name for this graph definition (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the graph definition. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name for this graph definition (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the capability statement.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The status of this graph definition. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment:
Allows filtering of graph definitions that are appropriate for use versus not.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired {{title}} without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this graph definition is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of graph definitions that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level graph definition.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If absent, this resource is treated as though it is not experimental.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the graph definition was last significantly changed. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the graph definition changes.
element.comment:
The date is often not tracked until the resource is published, but may be present on draft content. Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the graph definition. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name of the publisher/steward (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual responsible for the release and ongoing maintenance of the graph definition.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the graph definition is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the graph definition. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the graph definition. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the graph definition.  May also allow for contact.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment:
May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Natural language description of the graph definition
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the graph definition from a consumer's perspective.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the graph definition as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the graph definition is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the graph definition was created).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate graph definition instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Intended jurisdiction for graph definition (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the graph definition is intended to be used.
element.comment:
It may be possible for the graph definition to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

DEPRECATION NOTE: For consistency, implementations are encouraged to migrate to using the new 'jurisdiction' code in the useContext element.  (I.e. useContext.code indicating http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/usage-context-type#jurisdiction and useContext.valueCodeableConcept indicating the jurisdiction.)

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.short: Why this graph definition is defined
element.definition: Explanation of why this graph definition is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the graph definition. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this graph definition.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the graph definition and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the graph definition.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the graph definition.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A short string (<50 characters), suitable for inclusion in a page footer that identifies the copyright holder, effective period, and optionally whether rights are resctricted. (e.g. 'All rights reserved', 'Some rights reserved').
element.comment: The (c) symbol should NOT be included in this string. It will be added by software when rendering the notation. Full details about licensing, restrictions, warrantees, etc. goes in the more general 'copyright' element.
element.requirements: Defines the content expected to be rendered in all representations of the artifact.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The Node at which instances of this graph start. If there is no nominated start, the graph can start at any of the nodes.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Potential target for the link.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: Internal ID - target for link references
element.definition: Internal ID of node - target for link references.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Information about why this node is of interest in this graph definition.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Type of resource this link refers to
element.definition: Type of resource this link refers to.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A type of resource, or a Reference (from all versions)

element.definition: Profile for the target resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Links this graph makes rules about
element.definition: Links this graph makes rules about.

element.definition: Information about why this link is of interest in this graph definition.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Minimum occurrences for this link.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Maximum occurrences for this link.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The source node for this link.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Path in the resource that contains the link
element.definition: A FHIRPath expression that identifies one of FHIR References to other resources.
element.comment: The path expression cannot contain a resolve() function. If there is no path, the link is a reverse lookup, using target.params. If the path is "*" then this means all references in the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Which slice (if profiled).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The target node for this link.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A set of parameters to look up.
element.comment: At least one of the parameters must have the value {ref} which identifies the focus resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Compartment Consistency Rules.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Defines how the compartment rule is used - whether it it is used to test whether resources are subject to the rule, or whether it is a rule that must be followed.
element.comment: All conditional rules are evaluated; if they are true, then the rules are evaluated.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: identical | matching | different | no-rule | custom.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Patient | Encounter | RelatedPerson | Practitioner | Device | EpisodeOfCare
element.definition: Identifies the compartment.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Custom rule, as a FHIRPath expression
element.definition: Custom rule, as a FHIRPath expression.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Documentation for FHIRPath expression.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Definition of a graph of resources
element.definition: A formal computable definition of a graph of resources - that is, a coherent set of resources that form a graph by following references. The Graph Definition resource defines a set and makes rules about the set.

constraint.human: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation

element.short: Canonical identifier for this graph definition, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this graph definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which an authoritative instance of this graph definition is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the graph definition is stored on different servers.
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.

The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions). 

In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.
element.requirements: Allows the graph definition to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

constraint.human: URL should not contain | or # - these characters make processing canonical references problematic

element.short: Additional identifier for the GraphDefinition (business identifier)
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this GraphDefinition when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.short: Business version of the graph definition
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the graph definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the graph definition author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.comment: There may be different graph definition instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the graph definition with the format [url]|[version]. The version SHOULD NOT contain a '#' - see [Business Version](resource.html#bv-format).

element.definition: Indicates the mechanism used to compare versions to determine which is more current.
element.comment: If set as a string, this is a FHIRPath expression that has two additional context variables passed in - %version1 and %version2 and will return a negative number if version1 is newer, a positive number if version2 and a 0 if the version ordering can't be successfully be determined.

element.short: Name for this graph definition (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the graph definition. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

element.short: Name for this graph definition (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the capability statement.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

element.definition: The status of this graph definition. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment:
Allows filtering of graph definitions that are appropriate for use versus not.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired {{title}} without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this graph definition is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of graph definitions that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level graph definition.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If absent, this resource is treated as though it is not experimental.

element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the graph definition was last significantly changed. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the graph definition changes.
element.comment:
The date is often not tracked until the resource is published, but may be present on draft content. Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the graph definition. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

element.short: Name of the publisher/steward (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual responsible for the release and ongoing maintenance of the graph definition.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the graph definition is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the graph definition. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the graph definition. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the graph definition.  May also allow for contact.

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment:
May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

element.short: Natural language description of the graph definition
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the graph definition from a consumer's perspective.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the graph definition as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the graph definition is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the graph definition was created).

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate graph definition instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

element.short: Intended jurisdiction for graph definition (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the graph definition is intended to be used.
element.comment:
It may be possible for the graph definition to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

DEPRECATION NOTE: For consistency, implementations are encouraged to migrate to using the new 'jurisdiction' code in the useContext element.  (I.e. useContext.code indicating http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/usage-context-type#jurisdiction and useContext.valueCodeableConcept indicating the jurisdiction.)

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.short: Why this graph definition is defined
element.definition: Explanation of why this graph definition is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the graph definition. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this graph definition.

element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the graph definition and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the graph definition.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the graph definition.

element.definition: A short string (<50 characters), suitable for inclusion in a page footer that identifies the copyright holder, effective period, and optionally whether rights are resctricted. (e.g. 'All rights reserved', 'Some rights reserved').
element.comment: The (c) symbol should NOT be included in this string. It will be added by software when rendering the notation. Full details about licensing, restrictions, warrantees, etc. goes in the more general 'copyright' element.
element.requirements: Defines the content expected to be rendered in all representations of the artifact.

element.definition: The Node at which instances of this graph start. If there is no nominated start, the graph can start at any of the nodes.
Potential target for the link.

element.short: Internal ID - target for link references
element.definition: Internal ID of node - target for link references.
Information about why this node is of interest in this graph definition.

element.short: Type of resource this link refers to
element.definition: Type of resource this link refers to.

binding.description: A type of resource, or a Reference (from all versions)

element.definition: Profile for the target resource.

element.short: Links this graph makes rules about
element.definition: Links this graph makes rules about.
Information about why this link is of interest in this graph definition.
Minimum occurrences for this link.
Maximum occurrences for this link.
The source node for this link.

element.short: Path in the resource that contains the link
element.definition: A FHIRPath expression that identifies one of FHIR References to other resources.
element.comment: The path expression cannot contain a resolve() function. If there is no path, the link is a reverse lookup, using target.params. If the path is "*" then this means all references in the resource.

element.definition: Which slice (if profiled).
The target node for this link.
A set of parameters to look up.
element.comment: At least one of the parameters must have the value {ref} which identifies the focus resource.

element.definition: Compartment Consistency Rules.
Defines how the compartment rule is used - whether it it is used to test whether resources are subject to the rule, or whether it is a rule that must be followed.
element.comment: All conditional rules are evaluated; if they are true, then the rules are evaluated.

element.definition: identical | matching | different | no-rule | custom.

element.short: Patient | Encounter | RelatedPerson | Practitioner | Device | EpisodeOfCare
element.definition: Identifies the compartment.

element.short: Custom rule, as a FHIRPath expression
element.definition: Custom rule, as a FHIRPath expression.
Documentation for FHIRPath expression.
